TopicTitle: Ground Geological Surveying While On EVA

Articles.Content:
I've been thinking on the idea of how to increase the range of activities of what Kerbals can do without requiring a massive overhaul to some existing system, so I came up with the idea of adding a new feature. This feature is aiming at replicating how Apollo astronauts spent hours collecting rock samples and even drilling to get these samples; so here's my idea:

Kerbals on EVA can perform 'Ground Survey' and 'Drill Sample'.

Ground Surveys then have the game pick a random point within 2.0km of the Kerbal, but not informing the player of that point. The game however gives a pulse indicating which direction to head and it's proximity (sonar style). When the player reaches the point, they get a 'rock sample' which garners high science (varying on planet/moon). This specific trait would gain an increased harvest science point % when used by a scientist. Alternatively when performed by engineers, they get better distance pulses, and pilots get better directional indicators.

Ground Surveys would be when a EVA'd Kerbal attempts to drill a sample from the planet. This would yield different results when done by different classes; engineers would find the ore concentration in the area (dowser style), pilots would find the area information (name, latitude/longitude, etc), and scientists could earn more science. I have no idea what action this would take yet so it's up for discussion but I want it to be interactive like Ground Survey's and not just click and do like EVA Reports. My initial idea was for it to be a sliding action event, where you would hit a key (likely space by default) when the bar is over the indicated section, but I feel this isn't going to be widely approved hence why it's up for discussion.

Like I said, this was just an idea I've had for a while with no idea what to do with.

Not a bad idea. Basically random points of interest around a vessel like it is with the rover contracts.

However, I think what could be better would be the thing you suggest + minigame widgets. Basically, you take a few samples (they are somehow numbered/labeled based on where they were taken from), drive/fly back, take it to the lab and hit "Analyze". Then a widget with 2D representations (just so it's simpler to implement) of different instruments pops out and you got to do actual science. Heat the sample, take a look under the microscope and all that lab jazz. Depending on what you want to check for (ore, chemical elements and whatever else there is in regolith) you would do the actions in different orders.

I'll be honest, I'm not a geologist and I don't know how geology works, but IMO actual experimenting would be fun. Starbound has it neatly implemented in a form of archeology minigames and I enjoy them every time. Especially when there are rewards for it.
